JustJs

Heavily-used helpers for javascript environments.

Usage

JustJs distributes multiple files when a new version is released, therefore you should pick the one that better suits your needs...

Browser

Core [Default][Since v1.0.0]

Things you need for small/static websites.

Usage via CDN
core.js [Non minified version]
<script
												src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@just-js/just@%{latest-version}%/%{filename-dist-core}%"
												integrity="%{sri-dist-core}%"
												crossorigin="anonymous"
												async></script>
core.min.js [Minified version]
<script
												src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@just-js/just@%{latest-version}%/%{filename-dist-core-min}%"
												integrity="%{sri-dist-core-min}%"
												crossorigin="anonymous"
												async></script>

Full [Since v1.1.0]

The full suite to develop a medium/large website.

Usage via CDN
just.js [Non minified version]
<script
												src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@just-js/just@%{latest-version}%/%{filename-dist-just}%"
												integrity="%{sri-dist-just}%"
												crossorigin="anonymous"
												async></script>
just.min.js [Minified version]
<script
												src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@just-js/just@%{latest-version}%/%{filename-dist-just-min}%"
												integrity="%{sri-dist-just-min}%"
												crossorigin="anonymous"
												async></script>

Extra [Optional][Since v1.0.0]

polyfills.min.js [Minified version]
If you need to support ES5+, use this file.
Usage 
<script
												src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@just-js/just@%{latest-version}%/%{filename-dist-polyfills-ES5-min}%"
												integrity="%{sri-dist-polyfills-ES5-min}%"
												crossorigin="anonymous"
												async></script>

Server

Check available files on Github.

Read the documentation.

Usage

To use the latest version of JustJs on a server, install it via npm or via yarn:

Versioning

JustJs follows the Semantic Versioning Specification (SemVer) to version each release. However, we tag the release prepending "v" to the version.

Usually, you should avoid using release-candidates (those releases that include "-rc" on the version) and use a previous/next version instead, since those are used for testing purposes and removed after a release is no longer a candidate.

If you need more information about a certain version, please check the source code on Github.

%{available-versions-table}%
